title: Allow publishing source on Etherscan

labels.name: priority
labels.description: Should be included in next release

labels.name: Discussion
labels.description: Under discussion - not yet ready for implementation

body:
### Overview
It should be possible (and simple) to verify a deployed contract's source code on etherscan.

### Specification
Not 100% on how this would be best implemented. Some thoughts:

1. Add an internal "flattener" to turn multiple source files into a single file. Might also be worth exposing this on it's own via the CLI.
2. Add a method to `Contract`, to be called from in the console or a script.
3. Consider a flag in `brownie run` to auto-verify all sources after deployment?

Possible syntax:

```python
contract = ContractContainer.deploy({'from': accounts[0]})
contract.publish_on_etherscan()
```
and / or
```python
ContractContainer.deploy({'from': accounts[0]}, publish=True)
```
Does anyone work on this issue? if not, I would like to solve this issue.

Etherscan updated to support verifying from solidity-standard-json-input.

The `publish_on_etherscan` function should send [a POST like this](https://etherscan.io/sourcecode-demo.html).
What is the current best way to achieve this for contracts created trough `brownie`?
I think it would be good practice to have a `publish_sources: True|False` key that pushes to etherscan (or whatever block explorer) whenever a contract is deployed to a public network.

The json seems located in `build/contracts/` but where can I find the hex encoded constructor abi within `build/deployments/` ? 

https://github.com/eth-brownie/brownie/issues/766#issuecomment-711619114

edit: I was wrong, that is not the correct json.

Issue Status: 1. **Open** 2. Started 3. Submitted 4. Done

Add your own contribution [here](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068). * Questions? Checkout Gitcoin Help or the Gitcoin Chat * $1,045,515.92 more funded OSS Work available on the [Gitcoin Issue Explorer](https://gitcoin.co/explorer)
Looks like some of the work may have already started for this, but is blocked, in https://github.com/eth-brownie/brownie/issues/766?

Maybe we should also consider a standard json format instead of flattening for Solidity?
https://kndrck.co/posts/verify-contracts-etherscan-100/

Issue Status: 1. Open 2. **Started** 3. Submitted 4. Done 

<hr>

__Work has been started__.


These users each claimed they can complete the work by 266 years from now.
Please review their action plans below:


**1) [oogetyboogety](https://gitcoin.co/oogetyboogety) has been approved to start work.**

1) Create the internal flattener with an accessible CLI optoin and some standard for arranging/flattening multiple source files
2) add the publish_on_etherscan method to the contract conforming to the specs in https://etherscan.io/sourcecode-demo.html
3) add a build step in the brownie smart contract building and testing pipeline
**2) [developerfred](https://gitcoin.co/developerfred) has applied to start work _(Funders only: [approve worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068?mutate_worker_action=approve&worker=developerfred) | [reject worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068?mutate_worker_action=reject&worker=developerfred))_.**

My Plan and build this function in cli that self-identifies the contract models before delivering.  ex: contracts with experimental ABI and contracts with default ABI
**3) [hhio618](https://gitcoin.co/hhio618) has applied to start work _(Funders only: [approve worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068?mutate_worker_action=approve&worker=hhio618) | [reject worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068?mutate_worker_action=reject&worker=hhio618))_.**

My plan:
1. Add a flattener to brownie using this PyPI package: solidity-flattener.
2. Add a method to Contract to verify a source code on etherscan.
3. Add --auto-verify flag to brownie run.

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/eth-brownie/brownie/411/100024068).
@oogetyboogety sorry for the delay, I didn't notice I had to approve someone to start the work.
#651 could also be useful here.  I think verifying by submitting the standard JSON compiler input will be less error-prone.
@banteg  @iamdefinitelyahuman  I need to validate to make sure there are not more than 10 imports, right?

@banteg  how should the interface look for an etherscan API key? `solt` apparently uses some shared, potentially rate-limited API key[1] and I am trying to dig further into what this [2] means for brownie's use case of the verify & publish POST API:
`Someone using the tools from dapp.tools for instance, in conjunction with something like dapp-pm to manage their dependencies was out of luck until now, and I’ve tried to make it as easy as possible for users to get their deployed contracts verified with as little headache as possible. This means including all the API keys necessary so that (best case) you shouldn’t need to create, store, and manage your own Etherscan API key if you don’t want to, although you can do that as well.`
[1] https://github.com/hjubb/solt/blob/main/src/commonMain/kotlin/com/github/hjubb/solt/Verifier.kt#L79-L83
[2] https://blog.jubb.xyz/post/solt-release/
I would read from env variable. Other tools use `ETHERSCAN_TOKEN` or at least that's what I have in my env vars.
gotcha, thanks

Brownie is already expecting the API key as an environment variable `ETHERSCAN_TOKEN` elsewhere in the code, so this is the best option.

https://github.com/eth-brownie/brownie/blob/b7c72534adfadd29c136b21cb175e30c6437f7c0/brownie/network/contract.py#L1370-L1379

Right now i'm recompiling every time. I don't see anywhere where the output json from solc is stored, so I was trying to generate it again like this:

```
>>        input_json = compiler.generate_input_json(self._project._sources._contract_sources)
>>        output_json = compiler.compile_from_input_json(input_json)
```

should we be storing this in case this has already run? I guess my question is should we be caching solc's output json somewhere in a project or projectcontract from a contractcontainer/deployedcontractbase, if this is not already taking place? I looked but I don't see it being cached anywhere currently, as far as I can tell.

OK I think the etherscan API just takes the hex encoded input to the constructor in self.tx.input[2:]

Does this look right?
```
>>        post_data: Dict = {
                  "module": "contract",
                  "action": "verifysourcecode",
                  "codeformat": "solidity-standard-json-input",
                  "contractaddress": self.address,
                  "sourceCode": output_json,
                  "contractname": f"{output_json['contracts'].keys()[-1]}:{contract_name}",
                  "compilerversion": self._build['compiler']['version'],
                  "optimizationUsed": self._build['compiler']['optimizer']['enabled'],
                  "runs": self._build['compiler']['optimizer']['runs'],
                  "constructorArguments": self.tx.input[2:],
                  "evmversion": self._build['compiler']['evm_version'],
                  "licensetype": 1
              }
>>        for i, dependency in enumerate(self._build['dependencies']):
              if i <= 10:
                  post_data[f"libraryname{i}"] = dependency
                  if self._project[dependency][-1]:
>>                        post_data[f"libraryaddress{i}"] = self._project[library][-1].address[-40:]
              else:
                  raise Exception('Too many libraries to publish on explorer')
```

I seem to keep getting `ValueError: Failed to verify sourcecode from API: Pending in queue` in the PR

is there a paradigm you follow on backoff and retry of requests?

Thanks,
oogety
https://d1.awsstatic.com/builderslibrary/pdfs/timeouts-retries-and-backoff-with-jitter.pdf?did=ba_card-body&trk=ba_card-body

I get an exception in the code, but I guess it validates?
```
>>> t = accounts[0].deploy(project.TokenProject.Token, "Test Token", "ETH", None, None)
Transaction sent: 0xbfd0a9910b6048040618a1081e2b978e089088fc63de65782cfb5184457f1dc3
  Gas price: 5.00002159 gwei   Gas limit: 504546   Nonce: 23
  Token.constructor confirmed - Block: 9192203   Gas used: 458679 (90.91%)
  Token deployed at: 0x67f502cafC15a9783CBce4899F3e6671DC706e1F

>>> t.publish_to_explorer()
Verifying source of 0x67f502cafC15a9783CBce4899F3e6671DC706e1F from api-ropsten.etherscan.io...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/code/brownie/brownie/network/contract.py", line 543, in publish_to_explorer
    raise ValueError(f"Failed to verify sourcecode from API: {data['result']}")
ValueError: Failed to verify sourcecode from API: Pending in queue
```
But if you check Etherscan, you'll see where I validated brownie's input json manually and it realizes it's verified:
 Contract Source Code Verified (Similar Match)
Note: This contract matches the deployed ByteCode of the Source Code for Contract 0xcb61b5ec070c2ecebd219

So, I've got a little bit of work to do to figure out what I'm doing wrong to get a Pending result from the API here. I may need to touch base with Etherscan folks in some way.
@oogetyboogety rebase your branch, you are missing a lot of changes.
@Macarse think i fixed the conflicts now, i need to figure out some Pending error from the API, lint additions, write tests, and review the contributing guidelines for conformance
